dt: {bc}to put forth by way of {a_link|interference} or {a_link|intervention}
{bc}to introduce or throw in between the parts of a conversation or argument
{bc}to step in between parties at variance {bc}{sx|intervene||}

pt: {sc}interpose{/sc} {sc}interfere{/sc} {sc}intervene{/sc} {sc}mediate{/sc} {sc}intercede{/sc} mean to come or go between. {sc}interpose{/sc} often implies no more than this.

pt.t: {it}interposed{/it} herself between him and the door

pt: {sc}intervene{/sc} may imply an occurring in space or time between two things or a stepping in to stop a conflict.
{sc}intercede{/sc} implies acting for an offender in begging mercy or forgiveness.

et: Middle French {it}interposer{/it}, from Latin {it}interponere{/it} (perfect indicative {it}interposui{/it}), from {it}inter-{/it} + {it}ponere{/it} to put {ma}{mat|position|}{/ma}
shortdef: to place in an intervening position
to put forth by way of interference or intervention
